    Moisture-Stable Zn(II) Metal–Organic Framework as a Multifunctional Platform for Highly Efficient CO2 Capture and Nitro Pollutant Vapor Detection

    • Di-Ming Chen
      • , 
    • Jia-Yue Tian
      • , 
    • Min Chen
      • , 
    • Chun-Sen Liu*
      • , and 
    • Miao Du*

    Abstract

    A moisture-stable three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic framework (MOF), {(Me2NH2)[Zn2(bpydb)2(ATZ)](DMA)(NMF)2}n (1, where bpydb = 4,4′-(4,4′-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)dibenzoate, ATZ = deprotonated 5-aminotetrazole, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide, and NMF = N-methylformamide), with uncoordinated N-donor sites and charged framework skeleton was fabricated. This MOF exhibits interesting structural dynamic upon CO2 sorption at 195 K and high CO2/N2 (127) and CO2/CH4 (131) sorption selectivity at 298 K and 1 bar. Particularly, its CO2/CH4 selectivity is among the highest MOFs for selective CO2 separation. The results of Grand Canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation indicate that the polar framework contributes to the strong framework–CO2 binding at zero loading, and the tetrazole pillar contributes to the high CO2 uptake capacity at high loading. Furthermore, the solvent-responsive luminescent properties of 1 indicate that it could be utilized as a fluorescent sensor to detect trace amounts of nitrobenzene in both solvent and vapor systems.

    KEYWORDS:
    • metal−organic framework
    • moisture stability
    • dynamic structure
    • selective CO2 sorption
    • GCMC simulation

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    The past 20 years have witnessed a booming development of petrol industry and chemical manufacturing, accompanying which are the large emission of greenhouse gas CO2 and leakage of chemical pollutants into our living environment.(1-3) CO2 emission has led to many undesirable issues associated with rise of temperature, increase of sea levels, and climate change.(4) Meanwhile, the separation of CO2 from natural gases is demanded for facilitating energy conservation and generation of clean energy. As an important industrial material, nitrobenzene (NB) is widely used in inorganic synthesis, plastic processing, and pesticides, particularly the manufacture of aniline. At the same time, NB has been ranked as a dangerous pollutant in most countries for its high environmental and human health risks, and the search of sensors for quick detection of NB in both solvent and vapor systems is quite desirable.(5) As a type of burgeoning porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have shown great potential in many important areas, especially in selective greenhouse gas capture and environmental pollutants detection.(6-10) Their many features such as permanent porosity, high surface areas, adjustable pore surroundings, and variety of functional building blocks make them superior to other traditional porous materials (such as activated carbons and zeolites).(11) However, a major barrier limiting their practical applications is moisture instability, because many MOFs are assembled though weak metal–ligand coordination bonds and are more or less vulnerable to water molecules under an ambient atmospheric environment.(12) For instance, MOF-5 is very sensitive to moisture although it was intensively investigated for many kinds of possible applications.(13) Moisture is not negligible in CO2 separation and environmental pollutants detection processes. If MOFs are to be used in these areas mentioned above, their instability toward moisture needs to be overcome. Thanks to the tunable features of MOFs, their structures and properties could be finely modified by careful selection of building blocks which may lead to moisture-resist MOFs, such as using ligands with high pKa value or employing the classic Zr6 cluster as node.(14-18) In general, MOFs are constructed from metal ions or clusters as nodes and organic ligands as linkers, where the effect of organic ligands is more predictable for their designable and postfunctional natures.(19-21) Carboxylate-based ligands, due to their easy modification with specific groups, are most widely used in the construction of MOFs, but are commonly sensitive to water or even moisture for their weak M–O bonds.(22-24) 5-Amino-1H-tetrazole (HATZ) can act as a good coligand for preparing moisture-stable MOFs on the basis of the following considerations: (i) it can afford various H-bonds though the tetrazole and amino groups with the carboxylate ligand and charge balance ion which are helpful to stabilize the framework; (ii) the combination of carboxylate with tetrazole ligands tends to afford anionic coordination framework, and the charge-balance ions in the pores may also boost the rigidity of framework.(25-28) Thus, the employment of HATZ as coligand may be a nice choice to construct mixed-ligand MOFs systems with moisture-stable frameworks and additional functional sites.
    In a previous study, the structural transformation from a two-dimensional (2D) layered network to a three-dimensional (3D) pillar-layered framework by employing the mixed linkers of 4,4′-bipydine (4,4′-bpy) and 4,4′-(4,4′-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)dibenzoic acid (bpydbH2) was shown. Although the replacement of 4,4′-bpy with 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole could greatly improve the CO2 sorption capacity and selectivity, its poor moisture stability restricts its further investigation.(29, 30) In this contribution, a strategy with 5-aminotetrazole as the pillar is proposed to target a moisture-stable MOF {(Me2NH2)[Zn2(bpydb)2(ATZ)](DMA) (NMF)2}n (1, where ATZ = deprotonated 5-aminotetrazole, bpydb = 4,4′-(4,4′-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)dibenzoate, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide, and NMF = N-methylformamide), with a 2-fold interpenetrated dynamic framework. The sorption selectivity for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 was evaluated with the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST), and the calculated high selectivity for both mixed gases features this compound among the highest rank in MOFs for selective CO2 separation under ambient conditions. Furthermore, 1 could also be applied as an efficient fluorescent sensor to detect trace amounts of nitrobenzene in both solvent and vapor systems.

    Experimental Section

    Materials and Instruments

    The organic ligand bpydbH2 used in this work (Scheme 1) was synthesized by following the reported procedure.(29) C, H, and N elemental analyses were measured on a Vario EL III Elementar analyzer. Thermal analyses were recorded on the PerkinElmer Diamond SII thermal analyzer in the temperature range of 25 to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on the Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. CH4, N2, and CO2 sorption data were measured on a Micromeritics 3Flex surface area analyzer. A Varian Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer was used to record the luminescent spectra. The NB vapor test was carried out using a cuvette with a height of 3 cm and the width and length of 1 cm, at the bottom of which one drop of NB (about 24 mg) was carefully added.

    GCMC Simulation Details

    All the calculations were completed in the Materials Studio 6.0 package according to the literature method.(31) The atomic partial charges in the frameworks were calculated by QEq_neutral 1.0 method. The atomic locations were derived from the experimental crystal data and calculated charges were applied. The CO2 molecule was geometrically optimized by using the spin polarization density functional theory (DFT) on the basis of generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) function. The double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis 3.5 and DFT Semi-Core Pseudopots treatment were adopted. The calculated ESP charges for O and C atoms are −0.292 and 0.584 e, respectively. In the simulations, we have modeled the material framework and CO2 molecule as rigid and the universal force field (UFF) was applied. The simulation box contains 2 × 2 × 2 unit cells. Cutoff distance was set to 18.5 Å for the Lennard–Jones (LJ) interactions. The van der Waals interactions and electrostatic interactions were dealt with the Atom based and Ewald summation method. The favorable adsorption sites were simulated by the Locat task and Metropolis method. The loading steps, equilibration steps, and production steps were all set to 2 × 107. The snapshot for CO2 adsorption at high loading under room temperature was calculated by the Fix pressure task in the sorption model. The binding energy was calculated by the energy task in DMOL3 model based on the B3LYP function. The binding energy of CO2 was evaluated by the following equation:in which Eframework+gas is the total energy of framework and adsorbed CO2 molecule, and Eframework and Egas are the energies of the framework and CO2 molecule, respectively.

    Synthesis of {(Me2NH2)[Zn2(bpydb)2(ATZ)](DMA) (NMF)2}n (1)

    A mixture of bpydbH2 (0.040 g, 0.1 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.060 g, 0.2 mmol), HATZ (0.017 g, 0.2 mmol), DMA (2 mL), NMF (2 mL), and HBF4 (0.5 mL, 37% aq) was sealed into a vial (5 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. Yellow block crystals of 1 were harvested after the vial was slowly cooled to room temperature in 60% yield (based on bpydbH2). Anal. Calcd (%) for 1 (C59H57N13O11Zn2): C, 56.47; H, 4.58; N, 14.51. Found: C, 56.93; H, 4.77; N, 14.32.

    X-ray Crystallography

    Data collection of 1 was carried out on an Oxford Xcalibur Gemini Eos diffractometer using Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω-scan technique at 298 K. The structure was solved using SHELXS and refined with the full matrix least-squares method using SHELXL.(32) All the hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed in their ideal positions. The contribution from disordered guest solvents was removed by using the SQUEEZE program implemented in PLATON.(33) The final chemical formula of 1 was determined based on the single-crystal diffraction data together with thermogravimetric and elemental analysis. Details for structural analysis and selected bond lengths and angles are provided in SI Tables S1, S2, and S3, respectively.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Crystal Structure and Topological Analysis

    X-ray study shows that 1 belongs to the triclinic space group P1̅ with a doubly interpenetrated structure. The foundational unit of 1 consists of two Zn2+ ions, two bpydb2– ligands, one ATZ– ligand, and one dimethylamine cation. As shown in Figure 1a, the Zn2+ centers are both tetrahedrally coordinated with one pyridine N atom and two carboxylate O atoms from three different bpydb2– ligands, and the leaving site is bonded with the N atom from the ATZ– ligand. Each bpydb2– ligand acting as a tridentate node joins three adjacent Zn2+ centers with a monodentate mode to generate a 63 layered network (Figure 1b), and such networks are further extended to a 3D framework via the ATZ– pillars. In this case, each ATZ– pillar is only two-coordinated using its two N atoms, leaving two free N atoms and one −NH2 group as guest binding sites. Each 3D pillar-layered framework possesses a large one-dimensional (1D) hexagonal channel with the diameter of ca. 9.42 Å (the distance of H82 to H89 after subtraction of the van der Waals radii). Such a framework is large enough to allow another equivalent network to interpenetrate, forming a 2-fold interpenetrated framework possessing irregular 1D channels with diameters of 8.32 × 6.54 Å2 along c axis (Figure 1c and S1). Although 2-fold interpenetrated, 1 still possesses considerable free volumes of 30.5% accessible surface areas as revealed by PLATON calculation.(34) Topologically, the framework of 1 could be simplified as a 2-nodal (3,4)-connected net with the point symbol of (63)(65.8), which belongs to the jea topology (Figure 1d).(35)

    PXRD and TGA results

    The high phase purity of 1 was verified by well matching between the experimental PXRD pattern and the simulated one from the crystal data (Figure S2). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results reveal loss of DMA and NMF molecules with a total weight loss of 15.6% (calcd 16.3%) from 25 to 250 °C (Figure S3). The guest molecules incorporated in 1 can be removed by solvent exchange with CH2Cl2 and vacuum pumping at 30 °C for 24 h. The guest-free 1 (denoted as 1a) was verified by TGA on the activated sample, and 1a displays thermal stability similar to that of 1. However, the PXRD peaks of 1a are right-shifted compared with those of 1 (Figure S4), indicating a contracted framework,(36) and this can be further verified by N2 sorption at 77 K (see below). To demonstrate the chemical stability of 1, it was soaked in methanol, dichloromethane, and water for 1 day; the PXRD analysis confirms its crystalline nature but with a few peaks shifting and new peaks appearing (Figure S2), revealing the structural changes as such operation progresses. These experimental results may be attributed to the dynamic framework structure of 1, and similar results have also been reported in some interpenetrated MOFs.(37) Further attempts to determine these structures by single-crystal X-ray diffraction were unsuccessful due to the cracked crystals after solvent treatments.

    Gas Adsorption Properties

    The PXRD pattern shows the structure of 1a differs from that of 1 (Figure S4), with a few peaks shifting to the higher angles, indicative of a shrunk framework. As shown in Figure 2a, the framework stability and permanent porosity of 1a were verified by N2 sorption at 77 K, which shows a typical type I behavior with a small hysteresis between desorption and adsorption. This result reveals that the sample is a typical crystalline microporous material. On the basis of the N2 sorption isotherm, the calculated Langmuir and BET surface areas are 360 and 312 m2/g, respectively. The calculation from the N2 adsorption isotherm of 1a gives a total pore volume of 0.17 cm3/g, which is smaller than the one derived from crystal structure of 1 (0.26 cm3/g), confirming its shrunken structure after activation. The Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method was used to analyze pore-size distribution (PSD) on the basis of the 77 K N2-adsorption data, which gives a narrow pore size distribution at around 5.8–6.3 Å (Figure 2a, insert). The CO2 sorption isotherm at 195 K of 1a shows a stepwise adsorption and hysteresis desorption behavior (Figure 2b). The isotherm shows a very fast uptake at low pressure, and then achieves a plateau at 0.51 bar, after which another gentle increase in CO2 uptake appears, and finally ends with an uptake capacity of 132 cm3/g at 1.0 bar. This stepwise sorption behavior indicates that a structural transformation from a narrow pore (np) phase below 0.51 bar to a large pore (lp) phase above 0.51 bar might happen.(38) The DR analysis using the CO2 adsorption data in the lower pressure region (the first plateau) indicates a total pore volume of 0.19 cm3/g for the np form, which is near the value derived from the 77 K N2 adsorption isotherm (0.17 cm3/g), indicative of the structural similarity between the np form and 1a. At higher CO2 pressures (above 0.51 bar), the structure expands to the lp form with a pore volume of 0.25 cm3/g, which is near the one derived from the crystal structure of 1 (0.26 cm3/g). It should be noted that the phase transition will not be immediately reversible, so the desorption isotherm does not trace the steps of adsorption isotherm and this leads to a hysteresis loop. Such an unusual sorption behavior of 1a should be attributed to the larger quadrupole moment of CO2 (−1.4 × 10–39 cm2) than N2 (0 cm2), which can impose an interaction on the framework and induce a framework expansion.(38-41)
    Inspired by its permanent microporous feature and uncoordinated N atoms functionalized pores, we investigated its potential applications in CO2 capture and separation. The N2, CO2, and CH4 sorption isotherms of 1a were collected around room temperature. Notably, the tested temperatures here are not the representative of a realistic CO2 capture conditions and the results only aim to make a comparison with the other reported MOFs. At 273 K and 1 bar, 1a could take up 66.71 cm3/g (13.2 wt %) of CO2 (Figure 2c), while only small amounts of N2 and CH4 were adsorbed (8.46 cm3/g for CH4 and 4.29 cm3/g for N2). At 283 K and 1 bar, the CO2 uptake shows a slight decrease with a loading of 58.01 cm3/g (11.5 wt %). The measurements of CO2, N2, and CH4 sorption isotherms at 298 K reveal that 1a has low N2 and CH4 uptake (5.66 cm3/g for CH4 and 1.01 cm3/g for N2), but a relatively higher CO2 loading of 49.49 cm3/g (9.8 wt %). This CO2 loading of 1a, although being lower than that of some MOFs with high density of exposed metal-cations or appended amines, still out-performs those of many MOFs built up from the pillar-layered strategy with acylamide, amino, or triazolate functionalized pillars,(42-50) suggesting advantages of the amine functionalized tetrazole pillar in 1a for selective CO2 capture. The selectivity of 1a for CO2 over N2 and CH4 in binary mixtures theory were calculated by virtue of the ideal adsorbed solution.(51) MOF 1a shows high CO2/N2 selectivity with a value of 203 for 15:85 CO2/N2 mixture at 273 K and 1 bar (Figure 2d). As the temperature rises to 298 K, 1a still shows a high CO2/N2 selectivity of 127, which is higher than that of most MOFs functionalized with open metal sites, acylamide, or amino pillars constructed though the pillar-layered strategy, and is also comparable to some benchmark MOFs with high density of exposed metal-cations or appended amines.(42-50) The IAST selectivity was also calculated for CO2/CH4 mixtures (50% CO2 and 50% CH4, corresponding to the general feed compositions of landfill gas), where 1a shows high CO2/CH4 selectivity of 52 and 131 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. On decreasing the CO2 content to 5%, which corresponds to feed compositions of natural gas (5% CO2 and 95% CH4), 1a still shows high CO2/CH4 selectivity of 30 at 298 K and 1 bar (Figure S5). To our knowledge, the CO2/CH4 selectivity of 1a at 298 K surpasses the values of most MOFs reported recently with open metal sites and free N sites.(52-58)
    The high CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivity of 1a could be explained by its special pore environment, which features diversiform CO2 binding sites, for instance, N-rich tetrazole unite, free pyridine N atoms, and dimethylamine cations. These factors endow the framework with high polarity which could facilitate strong interactions with CO2 for its high polarizability and large quadrupole moment. The framework–CO2 interaction strength was evaluated by calculating the isosteric heat of CO2 via fitting the adsorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 298 K using virial equation. The Qst exhibits a value of 34 kJ/mol at zero loading and declines to a minimum value of 26 kJ/mol at the end coverage, which is typical for MOFs with strong binding sites. The Qst value is relatively higher as compared with the reported MOFs possessing exposed metal sites or free N sites.(47) To probe the advantages of −NH2 functionalized tetrazole pillars and polar frameworks upon CO2 sorption at the molecular level, the classic force field based Grand Canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations were carried out on the basis of the structure of 1. As shown in the Figure 3a, the favorable binding site of CO2 at zero loading was located near the dimethylamine cation and bpydb2– ligand, and many van der Waals interactions and H-bonds between CO2 and the open N atoms and polar H atoms on the dimethylamine cation could be observed, as well as π–π interactions with the bpydb2– ligand. These multiple CO2 binding sites form strong interactions with the calculated interaction energy of −33.7 kJ/mol, indicating that the polar framework of 1 contributes to the high Qst value at zero loading. Inspired by the pioneer work of Rosi et al., cation exchange experiments were also carried out.(59) However, the structures of 1 after cation exchanges indicate that the H2N(CH3)2+ guest in this case could not be exchanged by other cations. The snapshot from GCMC simulations for CO2 adsorption at 298 K and 1 bar was also calculated. As shown in Figure 3b, the CO2 molecules in 1 are mainly located in the relatively smaller channels near the −NH2 groups of tetrazole pillars.
    Moisture stability and recycling properties are crucial and important standards to evaluate an adsorption material for its further practical use. The moisture stability and regeneration of 1a were verified by leaving it in the air at a nominal relative humidity of 40–60% for one month.(60) According to the literature, moisture-unstable MOFs will show remarkable decrease in gas uptake capacity or even structure collapse when exposed to the ambient air.(61) The PXRD pattern of 1a is in good agreement with that of its original structural characteristics (Figure S7), revealing its framework integrity after staying in air for one month. Furthermore, this sample shows only a slight decrement for gas uptake (66.7 vs 62 cm3/g) compared with that of 1a during the three cycles of CO2 adsorption at 273 K, which further illustrates its moisture stability and regeneration ability (Figure 4).

    Fluorescent Behavior and Sensing Properties

    The solid state photoluminescent properties of 1 have been investigated at ambient temperature. Upon excitation at 325 nm, 1 shows intense emissions with a maximum peak at 410 nm and a shoulder at 517 nm (Figure S8). This observation agrees well with the compounds reported based on the bpydbH2 ligand, indicating a ligand-based luminescence.(62) To probe its potential applications as chemical sensors, the luminescent emissions of 1 in different solvent emulsions were examined (Figure 5a). The solvents used were ethyl formate, ethyl acetate, dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), acetonitrile, ethanol, methanol, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), acetone, DMA, dioxane, benzyl alcohol, and nitrobenzene (NB). The most noticeable feature is that its luminescence intensity could be selectively quenched by NB, while acetone and other solvents did not show much impact. These experimental results indicate that 1 might be used for the selective detection of NB molecules in solution. The sensing ability of 1 toward NB was studied by gradually increasing the NB concentration in 2.5 mL of DMF suspension containing 5 mg of finely dispersed 1. The luminescent intensity of the standard emulsion shows gradual decrease with the increased NB concentration and the intensity of 1–DMF standard emulsion decreased to 55% and 22% at 300 and 1000 ppm (Figure 5c). The luminescent intensity was nearly quenched when 5000 ppm of NB was added, and such a luminescence quenching phenomenon may be explained by the photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) mechanism.(63-66) It has been confirmed by the theoretical calculations that the electron could transfer from the excited organic ligand to electron-deficient nitrobenzene.(64) The frontier molecular orbitals of the bpydbH2 ligand and NB are calculated at the B3LYP level using density functional theory. As shown in Figure 5d, the LUMO of NB is lower than that of bpydbH2 ligand, so excited state electrons can transfer from 1 to NB, which leads to the luminescence quenching. To explore the quenching effect of NB in the present of other coexisting solvents, luminescent intensities of 1–DMF toward a mixture of NB and coexisting solvent (5000 ppm for each component) were also recorded, which would be almost unchanged in the presence of coexisting solvents (Figure S9). This result demonstrates that the quenching effect of 1 toward NB will not be influenced by the coexisting solvent.
    The excellent NB sensing performance of 1 in solution, as well as its good moisture and chemical stability, promoted us to investigative its NB detecting ability in the vapor state. As shown in Figure 6, a real-time solid-state luminescent sensor setup was applied. The time-dependent luminescence emission intensity of 1 shows a continuously decrease upon exposure to NB vapor, with a 50% fluorescence decrement in 1–2 min, which further decreased to 84.4% in 7 min. Such a response time is comparable to some outstanding MOFs reported for the NB vapor detection, and a much lower NB detection concentration in this work could be noted.(67-69) After detection of NB, the initial emission intensity of 1 could be recovered by heating up at 60 °C for 3 h, and reused for at least three cycles without loss of crystallinity and efficiency as evidenced by the PXRD patterns and three cycles’ experiments (Figure S10). As described in the Experimental Section, the in situ fluorescent measurements were performed in a cuvette with the volume of 3 cm3, corresponding to the NB concentration of 8.3 mg/cm3, which is much lower than the threshold limit value (5 mg/m3).(70) These experimental results suggest that 1 could be a promising sensor for recyclable detection of trace amounts of NB in the vapor state.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    A novel multifunctional MOF material bearing −NH2 functionalized tetrazole pillars has been successfully obtained. Its gas sorption and guest-dependent luminescent properties were systemically studied. This microporous framework shows not only an interesting structural dynamic but also high selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4 and N2 at room temperature. In addition, it exhibits the potential for luminescent detection of small molecules, particularly for toxic NB in both solvent and vapor systems with high sensitivity and selectivity. The current result also validates the strategy of introducing N-rich tetrazole auxiliary coligands to construct stable MOFs for CO2 capture and pollutants detection.

      Recent advances in carbon dioxide capture with metal-organic frameworks
      Liu, Yangyang; Wang, Zhiyong U.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Greenhouse Gases: Science and Technology (2012), 2 (4), 239-259CODEN: GGSTBK; ISSN:2152-3878. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. Uncontrolled massive release of the primary greenhouse gas carbon dioxide (CO2) into atm. from anthropogenic activities poses a big threat and adversely affects our global climate and natural environment. One promising approach to mitigate CO2 emission is carbon capture and storage (CCS), in which ideal adsorbent materials with high storage capacity and excellent adsorption selectivity over other gases are urgently needed. For practical applications in CO2 capture from flue gas of power plants, the biggest single contributor of anthropogenic CO2 emission, the adsorbent materials must also be chem. stable, be easy to regenerate with minimal energy input, and be easily synthesized with low capital cost. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), highly cryst. porous materials constructed by metal ions and org. ligands, have emerged as a class of excellent adsorbent materials for carbon capture. Great progress in MOF materials for CO2 capture has been made in the past and reviewed accordingly, but new discoveries are constantly being made as the field quickly grows. In this paper, we provide a short review on the most recent advances in using MOFs for CO2 adsorption, storage, and sepn. that are directly related to CO2 capture. Some of the important properties of MOF adsorbents which are crucial for practical applications but are largely overlooked in research carried out so far are discussed.

      Recent advances in solid sorbents for CO2 capture and new development trends
      Wang, Junya; Huang, Liang; Yang, Ruoyan; Zhang, Zhang; Wu, Jingwen; Gao, Yanshan; Wang, Qiang; O'Hare, Dermot; Zhong, Ziyi
      Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (11), 3478-3518CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Carbon dioxide (CO2) capture using solid sorbents has been recognized as a very promising technol. that has attracted intense attention from both academic and industrial fields in the last decade. It is astonishing that around 2000 papers have been published from 2011 to 2014 alone, which is less than three years after our first review paper in this journal on solid CO2 sorbents was published. In this short period, much progress has been made and the major research focus has more or less changed. Therefore, we feel that it is necessary to give a timely update on solid CO2 capture materials, although we still have to keep some important literature results published in the past years so as to keep the good continuity. We believe this work will benefit researchers working in both academic and industrial areas. In this paper, we still organize the CO2 sorbents according to their working temps. by classifying them as such: (1) low-temp. (<200 °C), (2) intermediate-temp. (200-400 °C), and (3) high-temp. (>400 °C). Since the sorption capacity, kinetics, recycling stability and cost are important parameters when evaluating a sorbent, these features will be carefully considered and discussed. In addn., due to the huge amts. of cost-effective CO2 sorbents demanded and the importance of waste resources, solid CO2 sorbents prepd. from waste resources and their performance are reviewed. Finally, the techno-economic assessments of various CO2 sorbents and technologies in real applications are briefly discussed.

      Multi-generation health risks of persistent organic pollution in the far north: use of the precautionary approach in the Stockholm Convention
      Godduhn, Anna; Duffy, Lawrence K.
      Environmental Science & Policy (2003), 6 (4), 341-353CODEN: ESCPFS; ISSN:1462-9011. (Elsevier)
      A review. Precautionary regulation of persistent, toxic substances is controversial because of continued and irresolvable uncertainties in ecotoxicol. This is esp. an issue for people who eat wild food, still a common practice in the Arctic. Persistent org. pollutants (POPs) have been shown to interfere with hormone function and genetic regulation. In animal studies, myriad dysfunctions can be induced (manifested later in life) by low-dose POPs exposure during development. The ubiquity of POPs in biol. tissue makes all organisms subject to developmental exposure. The Arctic, where subsistence living is common, is a sink region for POPs. To curtail bioaccumulation and biomagnification, the United Nations has created the Stockholm Convention in May 2001, which targets 12 chems. for virtual elimination. Using the precautionary approach, the treaty also enables the listing of new targets as threats are recognized. The dirty dozen are well-documented developmental toxics and other POPs are expected to exhibit similar patterns of accumulation and harm. Arctic peoples insist that waiting for irrefutable evidence is poor planning. Nevertheless, the United States, a major signatory, proved reluctant to ratify the language that would enable this expedient listing of new targets. Such reluctance allows health threats in the Arctic and around the world to grow. This paper reviews the theor. background for and current evidence regarding the global issues of endocrine disruption and POPs contamination, esp. as they relate to wildlife and people in the far north. There is an urgent need for the US to ratify the full text of the Stockholm Convention, including the provision for the listing of new targets.

      Amine Scrubbing for CO2 Capture
      Rochelle, Gary T.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 325 (5948), 1652-1654CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      A review. Amine scrubbing was used to sep. carbon dioxide (CO2) from natural gas and hydrogen since 1930. It is a robust technol. and is ready to be tested and used on a larger scale for CO2 capture from coal-fired power plants. The min. work requirement to sep. CO2 from coal-fired flue gas and compress CO2 to 150 bar is 0.11 MW-hours per metric ton of CO2. Process and solvent improvements should reduce the energy consumption to 0.2 MW-hour per ton of CO2. Other advanced technologies will not provide energy-efficient or timely solns. to CO2 emission from conventional coal-fired power plants.

      Luminescent metal-organic frameworks for chemical sensing and explosive detection
      Hu, Zhichao; Deibert, Benjamin J.; Li, Jing
      Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5815-5840CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a unique class of cryst. solids comprised of metal cations (or metal clusters) and org. ligands that have shown promise for a wide variety of applications. Over the past 15 years, research and development of these materials have become one of the most intensely and extensively pursued areas. A very interesting and well-investigated topic is their optical emission properties and related applications. Several reviews have provided a comprehensive overview covering many aspects of the subject up to 2011. This review intends to provide an update of work published since then and focuses on the photoluminescence (PL) properties of MOFs and their possible utility in chem. and biol. sensing and detection. The spectrum of this review includes the origin of luminescence in MOFs, the advantages of luminescent MOF (LMOF) based sensors, general strategies in designing sensory materials, and examples of various applications in sensing and detection.

      Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 724-781CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.

      11
      Metal-Organic Frameworks as Platforms for Functional Materials
      Cui, Yuanjing; Li, Bin; He, Huajun; Zhou, Wei; Chen, Banglin; Qian, Guodong
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2016), 49 (3), 483-493CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Discoveries of novel functional materials have played very important roles to the development of science and technologies and thus to benefit the authors' daily life. Among the diverse materials, metal-org. framework (MOF) materials are rapidly emerging as a unique type of porous and org./inorg. hybrid materials which can be simply self-assembled from their corresponding inorg. metal ions/clusters with org. linkers, and can be straightforwardly characterized by various anal. methods. In terms of porosity, they are superior to other known porous materials such as zeolites and carbon materials; exhibiting extremely high porosity with surface area up to 7000 m2/g, tunable pore sizes, and metrics through the interplay of both org. and inorg. components with the pore sizes ranging from 3 to 100 Å, and lowest framework d. down to 0.13 g/cm3. Such unique features have enabled metal-org. frameworks to exhibit great potentials for a broad range of applications in gas storage, gas sepns., enantioselective sepns., heterogeneous catalysis, chem. sensing and drug delivery. However, metal-org. frameworks can be also considered as org./inorg. self-assembled hybrid materials, the authors can take advantages of the phys. and chem. properties of both org. and inorg. components to develop their functional optical, photonic, and magnetic materials. Furthermore, the pores within MOFs can also be used to encapsulate a large no. of different species of diverse functions, so a variety of functional MOF/composite materials can be readily synthesized. In this Account, the authors describe the authors' recent research progress on pore and function engineering to develop functional MOF materials. The authors have been able to tune and optimize pore spaces, immobilize specific functional groups, and introduce chiral pore environments to target MOF materials for methane storage, light hydrocarbon sepns., enantioselective recognitions, carbon dioxide capture, and sepns. The intrinsic optical and photonic properties of metal ions and org. ligands, and guest mols. and/or ions can be collaboratively assembled and/or encapsulated into their frameworks, so the authors have realized a series of novel MOF materials as ratiometric luminescent thermometers, O2 sensors, white-light-emitting materials, nonlinear optical materials, two-photon pumped lasing materials, and two-photon responsive materials for 3D patterning and data storage. Thanks to the interplay of the dual functionalities of metal-org. frameworks (the inherent porosity, and the intrinsic phys. and chem. properties of inorg. and org. building blocks and encapsulated guest species), the authors' research efforts led to the development of functional MOF materials beyond the authors' initial imaginations.

      A Facile and General Coating Approach to Moisture/Water-Resistant Metal-Organic Frameworks with Intact Porosity
      Zhang, Wang; Hu, Yingli; Ge, Jin; Jiang, Hai-Long; Yu, Shu-Hong
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (49), 16978-16981CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The moisture sensitivity of many metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) poses a crit. issue for their large-scale real application. One of the most effective methods to solve this problem is to convert the surface of MOFs from hydrophilic to hydrophobic. Herein, we develop a general strategy to modify hydrophobic polydimethysiloxane (PDMS) on the surface of MOF materials to significantly enhance their moisture or water resistance by a facile vapor deposition technique. MOF-5, HKUST-1, and ZnBT as representative vulnerable MOFs were successfully coated by PDMS, and these coated samples well inherited their original cryst. nature and pore characteristics. Strikingly, the surface areas of these MOFs were nearly 100% retained upon PDMS-coating. Such a coating process might render MOFs applicable in the presence of water or humidity in extended fields such as gas sorption and catalysis.

      Enhanced Hydrostability in Ni-Doped MOF-5
      Li, Huanhuan; Shi, Wei; Zhao, Kaina; Li, Han; Bing, Yanmin; Cheng, Peng
      Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (17), 9200-9207CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Ni-doped MOF-5s were successfully synthesized for the 1st time via solvothermal crystn. process to enhance the hydrostability. Several characterization techniques, including XRD, thermogravimetrical anal.       High capacity, high selectivity, and low-cost regeneration conditions are the most important criteria by which new adsorbents for post-combustion CO2 capture will be judged. The incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine (mmen) into H3(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8 (CuBTTri; H3BTTri = 1,3,5-tri(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)benzene), a H2O-stable, triazolate-bridged framework, is shown to drastically enhance CO2 adsorption, resulting in one of the best performing metal-org. frameworks for CO2 sepn. reported to date. High porosity was maintained despite stoichiometric attachment of mmen to the open metal sites of the framework, resulting in a BET surface area of 870 m2 g-1. At 25° under a 0.15 bar CO2/0.75 bar N2 mixt., mmen-CuBTTri adsorbs 2.38 mmol CO2 g-1 (9.5%) with a selectivity of 327, as detd. using Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory (IAST). The high capacity and selectivity are consequences of the exceptionally large isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption, calcd. to be -96 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage. IR spectra support chemisorption between amines and CO2 as one of the primary mechanisms of uptake. Despite the large initial heat of adsorption, the CO2 uptake was fully reversible and the framework could be easily regenerated at 60°, enabling a cycling time of just 27 min with no loss of capacity over 72 adsorption/desorption cycles.

      Tuning the Topology and Functionality of Metal-Organic Frameworks by Ligand Design
      Zhao, Dan; Timmons, Daren J.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2011), 44 (2), 123-133CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) -highly cryst. hybrid materials that combine metal ions with rigid org. ligands- have emerged as an important class of porous materials. The org. ligands add flexibility and diversity to the chem. structures and functions of these materials. In this Account, we summarize our lab.'s experience in tuning the topol. and functionality of MOFs by ligand design. These investigations have led to new materials with interesting properties. By using a ligand that can adopt different symmetry conformations through free internal bond rotation, we have obtained two MOFs that are supramol. stereoisomers of each other at different reaction temps. In another case, where the dimerized ligands function as a D3-Piedfort unit spacer, we achieve chiral (10,3)-a networks. In the design of MOF-based materials for hydrogen and methane storage, we focused on increasing the gas affinity of frameworks by using ligands with different geometries to control the pore size and effectively introduce unsatd. metal centers (UMCs) into the framework. Framework interpenetration in PCN-6 (PCN stands for porous coordination network) can lead to higher hydrogen uptake. Because of the proper alignment of the UMCs, PCN-12 holds the record for uptake of hydrogen at 77 K/760 Torr. In the case of methane storage, PCN-14 with anthracene-derived ligand achieves breakthrough storage capacity, at a level 28% higher than the U.S. Department of Energy target. Selective gas adsorption requires a pore size comparable to that of the target gas mols.; therefore, we use bulky ligands and network interpenetration to reduce the pore size. In addn., with the help of an amphiphilic ligand, we were able to use temp. to continuously change pore size in a 2D layer MOF. Adding charge to an org. ligand can also stabilize frameworks. By ionizing the amine group within mesoMOF-1, the resulting electronic repulsion keeps the network from collapsing, giving rise to the first case of mesoporous MOF that demonstrates the type IV isotherm. We use dendritic hexacarboxylate ligands to synthesize an isoreticular series of MOFs with (3,24)-connected network topol. The cuboctahedral cages serve as building blocks that narrow the opening of the mesocavities into microwindows and stabilize these MOFs. The resulting materials have exceptionally high surface areas and hydrogen uptake capacities. Despite the many achievements in MOF development, there is still ample opportunity for further exploration. We will be continuing our efforts and look forward to contributing to this blossoming field in the next decade.

      Lin, Zu-Jin; Lu, Jian; Hong, Maochun; Cao, Rong
      Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5867-5895CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers (CPs), are cryst. materials constructed from metal ions or clusters bridged by org. ligands to form one-, two-, or three-dimensional infinite networks. In contrast with the prolific prodn. of MOFs based on rigid ligands (RL-MOFs), the design, syntheses and applications of MOFs based on flexible ligands (FL-MOFs) are somewhat overlooked. Although sacrificing a measure of control, the use of flexible ligands may provide unique opportunities to obtain novel cryst. framework materials exhibiting desirable attributes. In this review, emphasis has been placed on the design and the structural diversity of FL-MOFs. Homochiral FL-MOFs and dynamic frameworks induced by flexible ligands are also briefly outlined. An overview is also shown for the applications of FL-MOFs as platforms for gas adsorption, heterogeneous catalysis, proton conduction etc.

      Progress in adsorption-based CO2 capture by metal-organic frameworks
      Liu, Jian; Thallapally, Praveen K.; McGrail, B. Peter; Brown, Daryl R.; Liu, Jun
      Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (6), 2308-2322CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted intense research interest because of their permanent porous structures, large surface areas, and potential applications as novel adsorbents. The recent progress in adsorption-based CO2 capture by MOFs is reviewed and summarized in this crit. review. CO2 adsorption in MOFs has been divided into two sections, adsorption at high pressures and selective adsorption at approx. atm. pressures. Keys to CO2 adsorption in MOFs at high pressures and low pressures are summarized to be pore vols. of MOFs, and heats of adsorption, resp. Many MOFs have high CO2 selectivities over N2 and CH4. Water effects on CO2 adsorption in MOFs are presented and compared with benchmark zeolites. In addn., strategies appeared in the literature to enhance CO2 adsorption capacities and/or selectivities in MOFs have been summarized into three main categories, catenation and interpenetration, chem. bonding enhancement, and electrostatic force involvement. Besides the advantages, two main challenges of using MOFs in CO2 capture, the cost of synthesis and the stability toward water vapor, have been analyzed and possible solns. and path forward have been proposed to address the two challenges as well (150 refs.).

      A new mixed-ligand metal-org. framework (MOF), ZnATZ-BTB, has been constructed as a luminescent ratiometric thermometer by making use of the intrinsic dual emission at cryogenic temps.       A Guest-Dependent Approach to Retain Permanent Pores in Flexible Metal-Organic Frameworks by Cation Exchange
      Lin, Zu-Jin; Liu, Tian-Fu; Huang, Yuan-Biao; Lue, Jian; Cao, Rong
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (25), 7896-7902, S7896/1-S7896/23CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two anionic metal-org. frameworks were successfully prepd. based on pre-designed flexible multicarboxylate ligands and indium cations. Owing to the flexibility of the bridging org. linkers, which could not themselves sustain the frameworks, both of the frameworks showed thermal instability and shrinkage after removal of guest solvent mols.       34
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Directing the Breathing Behavior of Pillared-Layered Metal-Organic Frameworks via a Systematic Library of Functionalized Linkers Bearing Flexible Substituents
      Henke, Sebastian; Schneemann, Andreas; Wuetscher, Annika; Fischer, Roland A.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (22), 9464-9474CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Flexible metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also referred to as soft porous crystals (SPCs), show reversible structural transitions dependent on the nature and quantity of adsorbed guest mols. In recent studies it is reported that covalent functionalization of the org. linker can influence or even integrate framework flexibility (breathing) in MOFs. However, rational fine-tuning of such responsive properties is very desirable but challenging as well. Here the authors present a powerful approach for the targeted manipulation of responsiveness and framework flexibility of an important family of pillared-layered MOFs based on the parent structure [Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)]n (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane). A library of functionalized bdc-type linkers (fu-bdc), which bear addnl. dangling side groups at different positions of the benzene core (alkoxy groups of varying chain length with diverse functionalities and polarity), was generated. Synthesis of [Zn2(fu-bdc)2(dabco)]n yields the resp. collection of highly responsive MOFs. The parent MOF is only weakly flexible; however, the substituted frameworks of [Zn2(fu-bdc)2(dabco)]n contract drastically upon guest removal and expand again upon adsorption of DMF, EtOH, or CO2, etc., while N2 is hardly adsorbed and does not open the narrow-pored form. These breathing dynamics are attributed to the dangling side chains that act as immobilized guests, which interact with mobile guest mols. as well as with themselves and with the framework backbone. The structural details of the guest-free, contracted form and the gas sorption behavior (phase transition pressure, hysteresis loop) are highly dependent on the nature of the substituent at the linker and can therefore be adjusted using the authors' approach. Combining the authors' library of functionalized linkers with the concept of mixed-component MOFs (solid solns.) offers very rich addnl. dimensions of tailoring the structural dynamics and responsiveness. Implementation of two differently functionalized linkers in varying ratios yields multicomponent single-phased [Zn2(fu-bdc')2x(fu-bdc'')2-2x(dabco)]n MOFs (0 < x < 1) of increased inherent complexity, which feature a nonlinear dependence of their gas sorption properties on the applied ratio of components. Hence, the responsive behavior of such pillared-layered MOFs can be extensively tuned via an intelligent combination of functionalized linkers.

Overall, the performance characteristics of mmen-Mg2(dobpdc) indicate it to be an exceptional new adsorbent for CO2 capture, comparing favorably with both amine-grafted silicas and aq. amine solns.

      Construction of Non-Interpenetrated Charged Metal-Organic Frameworks with Doubly Pillared Layers: Pore Modification and Selective Gas Adsorption
      Sen, Susan; Neogi, Subhadip; Aijaz, Arshad; Xu, Qiang; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (14), 7591-7598CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The rigid and angular tetracarboxylic acid 1,3-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)imidazolium (H4L+), incorporating an imidazolium group, was used with different pyridine-based linkers to construct a series of non-interpenetrated cationic frameworks, {[Zn2(L)(bpy)2]·(NO3)·(DMF)6·(H2O)9}n (1), {[Zn2(L)(dpe)2]·(NO3)·(DMF)3·(H2O)2}n (2), and {[Zn2(L)(bpb)2]·(NO3)·(DMF)3·(H2O)4}n (3) [L = L3-, DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide, bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine, dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene, bpb = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene]. The frameworks consist of {[Zn2(L)]+}n two-dimensional layers that are further pillared by the linker ligands to form three-dimensional bipillared-layer porous structures. While the choice of the bent carboxylic acid ligand and formation of double pillars are major factors in achieving charged non-interpenetrated frameworks, lengths of the pillar linkers direct the pore modulation. Accordingly, the N2 gas adsorption capacity of the activated frameworks (1a-3a) increases with increasing pillar length. Moreover, variation in the electronic environment and marked difference in the pore sizes of frameworks permit selective CO2 adsorption over N2, where 3a exhibits the highest selectivity. In contrast, the selectivity of CO2 over CH4 is reversed and follows the order 1a > 2a > 3a. Even though the pore sizes of the frameworks are large enough compared to the kinetic diams. of the excluded gas mols., the electronic environment is crucial for the selective sorption of CO2.

      Molecular-level Insight into Unusual Low Pressure CO2 Affinity in Pillared Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Burtch, Nicholas C.; Jasuja, Himanshu; Dubbeldam, David; Walton, Krista S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (19), 7172-7180CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Fundamental insight into how low pressure adsorption properties are affected by chem. functionalization is crit. to the development of next-generation porous materials for post-combustion CO2 capture. The authors present a systematic approach to understanding low pressure CO2 affinity in isostructural metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) using mol. simulations and apply it to obtain quant., mol.-level insight into interesting exptl. low pressure adsorption trends in a series of pillared MOFs. The exptl. results show that increasing the no. of nonpolar functional groups on the benzene dicarboxylate (BDC) linker in the pillared DMOF-1 [Zn2(BDC)2(DABCO)] structure is an effective way to tune the CO2 Henry's coeff. in this isostructural series. These findings are contrary to the common scenario where polar functional groups induce the greatest increase in low pressure affinity through polarization of the CO2 mol. Instead, MOFs in this isostructural series contg. nitro, hydroxyl, fluorine, chlorine, and bromine functional groups result in little increase to the low pressure CO2 affinity. Strong agreement between simulated and exptl. Henry's coeff. values is obtained from simulations on representative structures, and a powerful yet simple approach involving the anal. of the simulated heats of adsorption, adsorbate d. distributions, and min. energy 0 K binding sites is presented to elucidate the intermol. interactions governing these interesting trends. Through a combined exptl. and simulation approach, the authors demonstrate how subtle, structure-specific differences in CO2 affinity induced by functionalization can be understood at the mol.-level through classical simulations. This work also illustrates how structure-property relationships resulting from chem. functionalization can be very specific to the topol. and electrostatic environment in the structure of interest. Given the excellent agreement between expts. and simulation, predicted CO2 selectivities over N2, CH4, and CO are also investigated to demonstrate that Me groups also provide the greatest increase in CO2 selectivity relative to the other functional groups. These results indicate that Me ligand functionalization may be a promising approach for creating both water stable and CO2 selective variations of other MOFs for various industrial applications.

      Design of Pore Size and Functionality in Pillar-Layered Zn-Triazolate-Dicarboxylate Frameworks and Their High CO2/CH4 and C2 Hydrocarbons/CH4 Selectivity
      Zhai, Quan-Guo; Bai, Ni; Li, Shu'ni; Bu, Xianhui; Feng, Pingyun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (20), 9862-9868CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      In the design of new materials, those with rare and exceptional compositional and structural features are often highly valued and sought after. However, materials with common and more accessible modes can often provide richer and unsurpassed compositional and structural variety that makes them a more suitable platform for systematically probing the compn.-structure-property correlation. The authors focus here on one such class of materials, pillar-layered metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), because different pore size and shape as well as functionality can be controlled and adjusted by using pillars with different geometrical and chem. features. The authors' approach takes advantage of the readily accessible layered Zn-1,2,4-triazolate motif and diverse dicarboxylate ligands with variable length and functional groups, to prep. seven Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillar-layered MOFs. Six different gases (N2, H2, CO2, C2H2, C2H4, and CH4) were used to systematically examine the dependency of gas sorption properties on chem. and geometrical properties of those MOFs as well as their potential applications in gas storage and sepn. All of these pillar-layered MOFs show not only remarkable CO2 uptake capacity, but also high CO2 over CH4 and C2 hydrocarbons over CH4 selectivity. An interesting observation is that the BDC ligand (BDC = benzenedicarboxylate) led to a material with the CO2 uptake outperforming all other metal-triazolate-dicarboxylate MOFs, even though most of them are decorated with amino groups, generally believed to be a key factor for high CO2 uptake. Overall, the data show that the exploration of the synergistic effect resulting from combined tuning of functional groups and pore size may be a promising strategy to develop materials with the optimum integration of geometrical and chem. factors for the highest possible gas adsorption capacity and sepn. performance.

      Water Stability of Microporous Coordination Polymers and the Adsorption of Pharmaceuticals from Water
      Cychosz, Katie A.; Matzger, Adam J.
      Langmuir (2010), 26 (22), 17198-17202CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      The stability of a variety of microporous coordination polymers (MCPs) to water-contg. solns. was studied using powder x-ray diffraction. The stability of the MCP is related to the metal cluster present in the structure with trinuclear chromium clusters more stable than copper paddlewheel clusters which are more stable than basic zinc acetate clusters. Zn(2-methylimidizolate)2 is more water stable than zinc MCPs with carboxylate linkers; however, extended exposure to water led to decompn. of all zinc-based MCPs. Materiaux de l'Institut Lavoisier (MIL)-100 also is completely water stable and was used to adsorb the pharmaceuticals furosemide and sulfasalazine from water with large uptakes achievable at low concns., indicating that the adsorption of wastewater contaminants may be a feasible application for these materials.

      Syntheses, structures and physical properties of transition metal-organic frameworks assembled from trigonal heterofunctional ligands
      Song, Shu-Yan; Song, Xue-Zhi; Zhao, Shu-Na; Qin, Chao; Su, Sheng-Qun; Zhu, Min; Hao, Zhao-Min; Zhang, Hong-Jie
      Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (34), 10412-10421CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Six novel metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), {Mn(bpydb)(bpyHdbH)}n (1) {[Co2(bpydb)2](H2O)0.5}n (2), {[Ni0.5(bpydbH)(H2O)](DMF)2}n (3), {[Cu2(bpydb)2](H2O)0.5}n (4), {Zn(bpyHdb)2}n (5) and {[Cd0.5(bpydb)0.5(DMF)](H2O)}n (6), were successfully synthesized by assembling transition metal salts with trigonal heterofunctional ligand 4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl) dibenzoic acid (bpydbH2) under hydrothermal and/or solvothermal conditions. Compd. 1 features a rare 4-fold interpenetrating (3,5)-connected framework with hms-type topol. Isostructural compds. 2 and 4, constructed by M2(COO)4 secondary building units, exhibit a robust 3D framework with alb topol. type in 2-fold interpenetrating mode. Compd. 3 consists of 2D (4,4) networks, which are further assembled into the new topol. framework with the symbol (53·62·8)(53·63)2 through O-H···O interactions. Compd. 5 manifests a novel 4-connected interpenetrating framework, constructed by 2D (4,4) layers and interbedded N-H···O interactions. Non-interpenetrating honeycomb networks are obsd. in compd. 6, and further packed into a 3D framework featuring 1D channels. The magnetic susceptibility of compd. 2 indicates antiferromagnetic interactions between cobalt ions. The photoluminescent properties of 5 and 6 were investigated in the solid state at room temp.

      Highly Selective Detection of Nitro Explosives by a Luminescent Metal-Organic Framework
      Nagarkar, Sanjog S.; Joarder, Biplab; Chaudhari, Abhijeet K.; Mukherjee, Soumya; Ghosh, Sujit K.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2013), 52 (10), 2881-2885CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The compd. exhibited selective detection of TNP, even in the presence of other nitro compds. in both aq. and org. soln. The selectivity is ascribed to electron and energy transfer mechanisms, as well as electrostatic interactions between TNP and the fluorophore. Despite the limited water stability and the toxicity of the reported CdII MOF, the results demonstrate a promising approach to achieve highly selective TNP sensing in MOFs. Thus, the luminescent porous MOFs with high water stability, large spectral overlap, and electrostatic interactions with TNP, could be promising candidates for practical TNP sensing by S. Ramachandra et al.(2011). Finally, the present study provides a new insight into the design of MOF-based explosive sensors, which are likely to be useful under more realistic conditions in the near future.

      Luminescent metal-organic frameworks as explosive sensors
      Banerjee, Debasis; Hu, Zhichao; Li, Jing
      Dalton Transactions (2014), 43 (28), 10668-10685CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal org. frameworks (MOFs) are of enormous current interest not only because of their fundamental importance but also due to their great potential for possible applications in gas storage and sepn., catalysis, imaging and sensing, to name a few. Recent studies on luminescent MOFs (LMOFs) in both bulk and nanoparticle forms have shown that these materials possess excellent luminescence emission properties that may be utilized to effectively detect high explosive substances. Developing highly sensitive, selective, fast-responding and fully reversible sensors for explosives' detection is in great demand for the homeland security, environmental safety and other humanitarian concerns. In this perspective article, the authors discuss the development, possible mechanism and future aspects of explosive sensing by LMOF materials.

      Solvent-Induced Topological Diversity of Two Zn(II) Metal-Organic Frameworks and High Sensitivity in Recyclable Detection of Nitrobenzene
      Chen, Di-Ming; Ma, Xiao-Zhou; Shi, Wei; Cheng, Peng
      Crystal Growth & Design (2015), 15 (8), 3999-4004CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      The solvent-induced topol. diversity and different framework stabilities were studied in two Zn(II) metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), {[Zn(L)]·DMA}n (1) and {[Zn(L)]·MeOH·0.5NMP}n (2) (H2L = 5-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)isophthalic acid). Despite the fact that both of these MOFs are (3,6)-connected networks based on the same coordination environment of Zn(II) ions and the same coordination mode of the ligands, they adopt distinct nets with apo and rtl topologies, resp., which originate from the template effects of the solvents and the conformational flexibility of the ligand. The two Zn(II) MOFs show remarkably different framework stability upon guest exchange due to their different topol. structures. The luminescent properties of MOF 1 with different solvents have been studied in detail, which shows high sensitivity in the detection of nitrobenzene (NB). In addn., MOF 1 can be reused by simply washing with fresh solvent.

      Zou, Ruyi; Ren, Xueling; Huang, Fang; Zhao, Yifang; Liu, Jia; Jing, Xiping; Liao, Fuhui; Wang, Yinxia; Lin, Jianhua; Zou, Ruqiang; Sun, Junliang

      An ultrastable porous metal-organic framework luminescent switch towards aromatic compounds
      Yi, Fei-Yan; Wang, Ying; Li, Jian-Ping; Wu, Dai; Lan, Ya-Qian; Sun, Zhong-Ming
      Materials Horizons (2015), 2 (2), 245-251CODEN: MHAOBM; ISSN:2051-6355. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A highly stable MOF luminescent switch {Cd3(L)(bipy)2·4DMA}n (1) has been successfully constructed, which exhibits clear fluorescence enhancement and "turn-off" quenching responses for benzene and nitrobenzene vapors, resp., with high selectivity and sensitivity, as well as being fully reusable.         Liu, Y.; Wang, Z. U.; Zhou, H.-C. Recent Advances in Carbon Dioxide Capture with Metal–Organic Frameworks Greenhouse Gases: Sci. Technol. 2012, 2, 239– 259 DOI: 10.1002/ghg.1296

        1
        Recent advances in carbon dioxide capture with metal-organic frameworks
        Liu, Yangyang; Wang, Zhiyong U.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Greenhouse Gases: Science and Technology (2012), 2 (4), 239-259CODEN: GGSTBK; ISSN:2152-3878. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        A review. Uncontrolled massive release of the primary greenhouse gas carbon dioxide (CO2) into atm. from anthropogenic activities poses a big threat and adversely affects our global climate and natural environment. One promising approach to mitigate CO2 emission is carbon capture and storage (CCS), in which ideal adsorbent materials with high storage capacity and excellent adsorption selectivity over other gases are urgently needed. For practical applications in CO2 capture from flue gas of power plants, the biggest single contributor of anthropogenic CO2 emission, the adsorbent materials must also be chem. stable, be easy to regenerate with minimal energy input, and be easily synthesized with low capital cost. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), highly cryst. porous materials constructed by metal ions and org. ligands, have emerged as a class of excellent adsorbent materials for carbon capture. Great progress in MOF materials for CO2 capture has been made in the past and reviewed accordingly, but new discoveries are constantly being made as the field quickly grows. In this paper, we provide a short review on the most recent advances in using MOFs for CO2 adsorption, storage, and sepn. that are directly related to CO2 capture. Some of the important properties of MOF adsorbents which are crucial for practical applications but are largely overlooked in research carried out so far are discussed.

        2
        Recent advances in solid sorbents for CO2 capture and new development trends
        Wang, Junya; Huang, Liang; Yang, Ruoyan; Zhang, Zhang; Wu, Jingwen; Gao, Yanshan; Wang, Qiang; O'Hare, Dermot; Zhong, Ziyi
        Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (11), 3478-3518CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Carbon dioxide (CO2) capture using solid sorbents has been recognized as a very promising technol. that has attracted intense attention from both academic and industrial fields in the last decade. It is astonishing that around 2000 papers have been published from 2011 to 2014 alone, which is less than three years after our first review paper in this journal on solid CO2 sorbents was published. In this short period, much progress has been made and the major research focus has more or less changed. Therefore, we feel that it is necessary to give a timely update on solid CO2 capture materials, although we still have to keep some important literature results published in the past years so as to keep the good continuity. We believe this work will benefit researchers working in both academic and industrial areas. In this paper, we still organize the CO2 sorbents according to their working temps. by classifying them as such: (1) low-temp. (<200 °C), (2) intermediate-temp. (200-400 °C), and (3) high-temp. (>400 °C). Since the sorption capacity, kinetics, recycling stability and cost are important parameters when evaluating a sorbent, these features will be carefully considered and discussed. In addn., due to the huge amts. of cost-effective CO2 sorbents demanded and the importance of waste resources, solid CO2 sorbents prepd. from waste resources and their performance are reviewed. Finally, the techno-economic assessments of various CO2 sorbents and technologies in real applications are briefly discussed.

        Godduhn, A.; Duffy, L. K. Multi-generation Health Risks of Persistent Organic Pollution in the Far North: Use of the Precautionary Approach in the Stockholm Convention Environ. Sci. Policy 2003, 6, 341– 353 DOI: 10.1016/S1462-9011(03)00061-3
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Multi-generation health risks of persistent organic pollution in the far north: use of the precautionary approach in the Stockholm Convention
        Godduhn, Anna; Duffy, Lawrence K.
        Environmental Science & Policy (2003), 6 (4), 341-353CODEN: ESCPFS; ISSN:1462-9011. (Elsevier)
        A review. Precautionary regulation of persistent, toxic substances is controversial because of continued and irresolvable uncertainties in ecotoxicol. This is esp. an issue for people who eat wild food, still a common practice in the Arctic. Persistent org. pollutants (POPs) have been shown to interfere with hormone function and genetic regulation. In animal studies, myriad dysfunctions can be induced (manifested later in life) by low-dose POPs exposure during development. The ubiquity of POPs in biol. tissue makes all organisms subject to developmental exposure. The Arctic, where subsistence living is common, is a sink region for POPs. To curtail bioaccumulation and biomagnification, the United Nations has created the Stockholm Convention in May 2001, which targets 12 chems. for virtual elimination. Using the precautionary approach, the treaty also enables the listing of new targets as threats are recognized. The dirty dozen are well-documented developmental toxics and other POPs are expected to exhibit similar patterns of accumulation and harm. Arctic peoples insist that waiting for irrefutable evidence is poor planning. Nevertheless, the United States, a major signatory, proved reluctant to ratify the language that would enable this expedient listing of new targets. Such reluctance allows health threats in the Arctic and around the world to grow. This paper reviews the theor. background for and current evidence regarding the global issues of endocrine disruption and POPs contamination, esp. as they relate to wildlife and people in the far north. There is an urgent need for the US to ratify the full text of the Stockholm Convention, including the provision for the listing of new targets.

        4
        Amine Scrubbing for CO2 Capture
        Rochelle, Gary T.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 325 (5948), 1652-1654CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A review. Amine scrubbing was used to sep. carbon dioxide (CO2) from natural gas and hydrogen since 1930. It is a robust technol. and is ready to be tested and used on a larger scale for CO2 capture from coal-fired power plants. The min. work requirement to sep. CO2 from coal-fired flue gas and compress CO2 to 150 bar is 0.11 MW-hours per metric ton of CO2. Process and solvent improvements should reduce the energy consumption to 0.2 MW-hour per ton of CO2. Other advanced technologies will not provide energy-efficient or timely solns. to CO2 emission from conventional coal-fired power plants.

        Luminescent metal-organic frameworks for chemical sensing and explosive detection
        Hu, Zhichao; Deibert, Benjamin J.; Li, Jing
        Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5815-5840CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a unique class of cryst. solids comprised of metal cations (or metal clusters) and org. ligands that have shown promise for a wide variety of applications. Over the past 15 years, research and development of these materials have become one of the most intensely and extensively pursued areas. A very interesting and well-investigated topic is their optical emission properties and related applications. Several reviews have provided a comprehensive overview covering many aspects of the subject up to 2011. This review intends to provide an update of work published since then and focuses on the photoluminescence (PL) properties of MOFs and their possible utility in chem. and biol. sensing and detection. The spectrum of this review includes the origin of luminescence in MOFs, the advantages of luminescent MOF (LMOF) based sensors, general strategies in designing sensory materials, and examples of various applications in sensing and detection.

        7
        Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 724-781CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.

        Divergent Kinetic and Thermodynamic Hydration of a Porous Cu(II) Coordination Polymer with Exclusive CO2 Sorption Selectivity
        Du, Miao; Li, Cheng-Peng; Chen, Min; Ge, Zhi-Wei; Wang, Xi; Wang, Lei; Liu, Chun-Sen
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (31), 10906-10909CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A MOF material, [Cu(tba)2]n (tba = 4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)benzoate), which shows high CO2 adsorption selectivity over CH4-H2-O2-Ar-N2 gases (with IAST selectivity of 41-68 at 273 K and 33-51 at 293 K) is reported. By using a crit. point dryer, the CO2 mols. can be well sealed in the 1D channels of [Cu(tba)2]n to allow a single-crystal X-ray anal., which reveals the presence of not only Cδ+-H···Oδ- bonds between the host framework and CO2 but also quadrupole- quadrupole (CO2δ-···δ+CO2) interactions between the CO2 mols. Furthermore, [Cu(tba)2]n will suffer divergent kinetic and thermodn. hydration processes to form its isostructural hydrate {[Cu(tba)2](H2O)}n and a mononuclear complex [Cu(tba)2(H2O)4] via single-crystal to single-crystal transformations.

        Cui, Y.; Li, B.; He, H.; Zhou, W.; Chen, B.; Qian, G. Metal–Organic Frameworks as Platforms for Functional Materials Acc. Chem. Res. 2016, 49, 483– 493 DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.5b00530
